explanation:
Needed symbols and why:
- lfs_t: required to know the declaration of the block_count field (type, qualifiers such as volatile, const, or whether it is computed/aliased). Whether lfs->block_count is an invariant depends on its definition.
- lfs_size_t: required to know the underlying integer type and value-range/representation of block_count (affects whether comparisons can be considered invariant).
- lfs_fs_grow (caller): the caller supplies the block_count argument; to determine whether the controlling expression (block_count == lfs->block_count) is invariant across calls we must inspect the caller to see what argument values it passes (and whether it always passes lfs->block_count itself).
- lfs_fs_traverse_: this function is invoked in the alternative branch (under LFS_SHRINKNONRELOCATING) with &block_count. We must know its signature/semantics to decide whether it or its callbacks can modify block_count (making the controlling expression non-invariant) or whether it guarantees no change.
- lfs_shrink_checkblock: the callback passed to lfs_fs_traverse_; it may modify the pointed-to block_count or otherwise affect invariance of the (block_count < lfs->block_count) test. Its behavior is needed to judge invariance.
- LFS_SHRINKNONRELOCATING (preprocessor macro): the presence/absence of this macro changes which runtime controlling expressions exist (the extra if (block_count < lfs->block_count) and the traverse call). Analysis must consider the compiled variant(s).
- LFS_ASSERT (macro): the assert in the #ifndef branch expands to code containing control expressions (or may be a no-op); its expansion determines whether additional controlling expressions (and their invariance) are introduced in the compiled function.

These symbols allow determination of whether the runtime controlling expressions in lfs_fs_grow_ are truly invariant (constant) or can vary, and whether any compile-time configuration removes/introduces controlling expressions (relevant for the MISRA rule).
